name: Ava Sauer
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info: This graph was created to reveal how calorie count and portion sizes have grown over the years. Across the board, it can be seen that even if portion sizes changed minimally, the calorie count went up. This can especially be seen in desserts, where the portion size went up by some but the calorie count nearly doubled. This graph says a lot about modern day food and how Americans eat. We have a culture based around fast food, which has tightened its grip over us in the past half century and in doing so has also lead to an increase in the consumption of calories. This ever-growing epidemic is what has led to America’s two biggest problems, diabetes and heart disease, and is a predicament that needs to be controlled before it gets completely out of control. From a very young age, American children are institutionalized to like fast food because companies market such food towards them, and this begins the cycle of addiction and consumption that leads to these problems. Promoting healthier eating from a young age would be one thing that could help to break such a cycle. In all, these graphs are a great demonstration of how unhealthy food has become.

name: Sahil Patel
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Part 1-
The higher and higher number of calories that Americans are eating every year is absolutely atrocious. By now, people should have realized the negative health consequences that come with continually eating at fast food restaurants. The serving size and calories of entrees, sides, and desserts at fast food chains have all increased significantly over the past thirty years. The category with the highest increased in calories was the desserts, which increased from 234 calories in 1986 to 420 calories in 2016, demonstrating that Americans continue to eat larger portions of more unhealthy foods. The number of calories in the average dessert is equal to the number of calories in an entree, clearly showing how unhealthy foods continue to dominate and prevail in fast food restaurants. The increasing unhealthiness of foods in restaurants is clearly a direct cause of the increasing levels of obesity in the United States.

comment info:
Part 2-
I wonder if the serving sizes and calories of various foods and restaurants will continue to increase perpetually. If so, Americans should be extremely concerned about their health and should avoid eating out as much as possible. The size of fast food servings has been increased to accommodate the growing size of Americans. The only way to avoid complicated health issues that are affecting people all over the country, such as obesity, are to bring those serving sizes and calories back down. Even better, people should ensure that the number of times they eat at fast food places is as minimal as possible in order to avoid the temptations of ordering high-calorie desserts and burgers. If the people in the U.S. want to decrease the levels of health problems such as diabetes, high cholesterol, and obesity in their country, they must restore the lower-calorie foods to restaurants or completely avoid eating at fast food places.

name: Grace R
comment info: This graph shows an increase in portion sizes and calories in fast food items in 1986, 1991, and 2016. The increase in size and amount of calories has steadily increased in entrees, sides, and desserts in fast food menus, although the largest increase occurred in the desert category. This increase probably relates to the growing obesity crisis in the United States and other countries. I wonder how the increases affects sales for the companies that sell these food products, and if the growing sizes and calories relate to a demand for larger portions. One headline for this graph could be "Sizing Up: Growing Fast Food Portions Continue to Climb."

name: Abby AOSE
comment info:
Headline: The Bigger The Better... Not so much

I notice that the portions have increased since 1986, along with the calorie count. Every course has increased, but it seems as if the entrees have gone up the most in regards to the calorie count. Also, the dessert calorie count has increased the most out of all the other dishes.

I wonder if the increase in cost of products has anything to do with the calorie to serving ratio. Also, does the fact that mass production is more popular have anything to do with the increase in calorie count? What will 2019 and 2020 look like as well?

name: Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

Today’s graphs include nutritional measures for the fast food categories of entrees, desserts, and sides (fries, salads, etc.).  For the years 1986, 1991, and 2016, researchers studied 1,787 menu offerings from 10 national chains.  Notice the statistics for a category over time and statistics among the categories.  Wonder how these changes are affecting our health.

From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, share with us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  

Then, share with us a catchy headline that captures the ideas about the graph. 

We welcome you replying directly to each other's comments. This is a great way to seek clarification on someone's comment.  Ask a follow-up question or to share a different idea or opinion in a respectful way.  

On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included this graph and much more.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

The next “What’s Going On in This Graph?” will be released tomorrow -- Thursday, OCTOBER 17 with moderation on Wednesday, OCTOBER 23.  The topic – the drop in pet euthanasia.

name: Sahil Patel
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Part 1-
The higher and higher number of calories that Americans are eating every year is absolutely atrocious. By now, people should have realized the negative health consequences that come with continually eating at fast food restaurants. The serving size and calories of entrees, sides, and desserts at fast food chains have all increased significantly over the past thirty years. The category with the highest increased in calories was the desserts, which increased from 234 calories in 1986 to 420 calories in 2016, demonstrating that Americans continue to eat larger portions of more unhealthy foods. The number of calories in the average dessert is equal to the number of calories in an entree, clearly showing how unhealthy foods continue to dominate and prevail in fast food restaurants. The increasing unhealthiness of foods in restaurants is clearly a direct cause of the increasing levels of obesity in the United States.

replies.name: M

name: Sahil Patel
location: Hoggard High School in Wilmington, NC
comment info:
Part 2-
I wonder if the serving sizes and calories of various foods and restaurants will continue to increase perpetually. If so, Americans should be extremely concerned about their health and should avoid eating out as much as possible. The size of fast food servings has been increased to accommodate the growing size of Americans. The only way to avoid complicated health issues that are affecting people all over the country, such as obesity, are to bring those serving sizes and calories back down. Even better, people should ensure that the number of times they eat at fast food places is as minimal as possible in order to avoid the temptations of ordering high-calorie desserts and burgers. If the people in the U.S. want to decrease the levels of health problems such as diabetes, high cholesterol, and obesity in their country, they must restore the lower-calorie foods to restaurants or completely avoid eating at fast food places.

As the description of the graph states, the portion size and calorie count increase significantly over the years. This could be due to a lot of things, such as globalization of large corporations, catering to the "growing" size of our populations, and other factors. The growing size of the fast food industry and competition among the corporations means that the food they serve could go in either direction in terms of quality. In an ideal society, close competition in the marketplace would lead to the competitors striving to attract more customers with higher quality items, however quite the opposite is true in the real world. Modern corporations reach for quantity over quality and market lies through heavy advertisement to drill their food ideas into the minds of the public. The graph could show the loss of quality in food through the use of lower quality and higher calorie items that contain sugars, sodium, fats, and preservatives so that the fast food joints could sell more food for less cost to the company.

In the U.S., we are facing an epidemic of obesity, and fast food corporations have fallen under the limelight of blame in past years for this issue. replies.comment info:
HI, @Julianna K --

Thank you for so many noticings and wonderings.

You wonder, “How much of an impact does fast-food have on obesity in American society?”  Fast food contributes to obesity in more countries than the United States.  You may want to check out the "What's Going On In This Graph? release (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/16/learning/whats-going-on-in-this-graph-oct-17-2018.html) from October 18, 2018.  It includes a graph from the article “Obesity Was Rising as Ghana Embraced Fast Food.  Then Came KFC.”  America is not the only place that dreams of fast food.

Please remember that there may be an association between fast food calories and obesity, but without a controlled randomized experiment you cannot say that there is causation.  There may be other factors.  To read more about the difference between association and causation, read this week's New York Times Upshot article "Five Reasons the Diet Soda Myth Won't Die" (https://www.nytimes.com/2019/10/14/upshot/diet-soda-health-myths.html).

replies.comment info:
Hi, @S. Pfeifer --

Yes, you were the first to respond.  Congratulations.  And, with a great collaborative list.  I hope you read my reply.

Some of the answers to your wonderings are in the journal article, which is behind a firewall.  I’ll share with you what I know and then ask you a question.

Why did they only do three categories?  
The researchers acknowledge that they did not analyze beverages (sizes in ounces were not always given) and either condiments, like ketchup, or multi-components meals, like combo meals (incomplete data for all restaurants and years).  

Why are the years spaced unevenly?  
The data was from different sources and that maybe why the years are not spaced evenly.  The 1986 and 1991 data was from “The Fast Food Guide:  What’s Good, What’s Bad, and How to Tell the Difference” and its update by Jacobson and Fritchner.  The 2016 data was from online websites.  

Why did they choose this style of graph?  
What other type of graph would you suggest?  You have the data so you can make another set of graphs with a different type of graph and compare their effectiveness.  Please share with us your conclusion.

PS    I taught at West Middle School in Waltham, MA years ago.  Is that your school?
